job_title: Director in San Antonio, TX
pros: The University offers a teacher retirement program to all employees. Health insurance is covered by the school and used to be excellent, it's still pretty good, but co-pays have gone way up. Time off is pretty good, but you can't always use it because of the workload expectations. The work can be meaningful when not inhibited by bureaucracy. Lots of the people I work with are good people and team players.
cons: Workload expectations are unrealistic, and accountability is not taken seriously at all. People seem to be burned out and the longer they are there the more bitter they seem to become. Instead of holding people accountable for poor performance or behavior they are often just moved from department to department. Salaries are not comparable to market pay and raises/promotions for deserving staff are few and far between. Every department I work with is short-staffed and being asked to do more and more without adequate support.

job_title: Administrative Manager in San Antonio, TX
pros: There are some great people to work with at UTSA.  Your colleagues, for the most part, are kind, helpful, and knowledge.  They all know that it takes everyone for the university to operate.  As an employee, you are automatically enrolled in the Teacher Retirement System and it takes 5 years of employment to be vested in it.  The leave policies are pretty standard and the HR team there is wonderful.  The students are wonderful too.
cons: The pay isn't competitive enough for the good people to want to stay at the university and there are a few bad eggs in leadership that make bad calls to either change a system that is working efficiently or to ignore pleas from staff to make certain processes more efficient.  Leadership is hit or miss and when they miss, it usually becasue they don't listen to the people that do the job every day and they don't stick up for their employees.  It's been a pretty consistent increase of doing more with less: less money, less employees, less resources, and less support.

review_title: Sadly, UTSA was a bitter disappointment
job_title: Academic Advisor I in San Antonio, TX
pros: Great health insurance benefits for the employee...free!  Earn 8 hours of sick leave per month and 8 hours of vacation per month.  M-F job.
cons: I guess I'm in the minority for reviews on glassdoor, but I have worked in 2 departments at UTSA and in both departments every FULL TIME employee was unhappy and miserable.  I found working at UTSA to be extremely inflexible, full of rules that really didn't make sense and there was a form for EVERYTHING.  Taking a day off is not permitted during your first 6 months of employment...why????  It was a paperwork process to request to leave work an hour early for a dental appointment.   Payday is once a month....HUGE minus, sometimes waiting 5 weeks to be paid again.  And, why does the state of Texas pay it's employees so poorly, yet administrators are earning in upwards of $250,000 and $300,000.  Come on, when you pay people with a Master's degree $30,000, how can you justify paying an administrator 10 times that amount.   PARKING!!!!  Employees have to pay for parking.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in San Antonio, TX
pros: Depends on the department and, more than that, on the professor. As an institution, UTSA offers either student or employee health insurance to GRAs but you must pay for it yourself.
cons: Pay is really low, and this for some reason depends on the department as well. My department pays a modest amount but I once got an offer from another department that was awful. The reasoning is that San Antonio is cheaper than many other cities but unless you are from SATX and live at home you'll find that to be overstated for their budgetary convenience. The university is lacking in facilities and services that might help compensate. The downtown campus is especially shoddy in this respect.

review_title: Office politics take priority over students
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Antonio, TX
pros: The students are great to work with. Good benefits and compensation. The HR training department is fantastic and provides lots of opportunities for personal and professional development.
cons:
The different departments and colleges are ultra competitive with each other, looking out for their own interests instead of those of the students, attitudes that are fostered from the top. There's little opportunity to develop strong relationships with colleagues because everyone operates in CYA mode. From my first day, I was warned by my boss to watch my back, and which people (who I would need to work with) I shouldn't trust, followed soon after with others giving me the same warning. Its bizarre when leadership is aware of how toxic the environment is but then tells you to roll with it.

After the death of my parent, I was criticized by new supervisor for taking time off for their funeral. That was a sign of how much more toxic the environment would become, and the beginning of the end.

review_title: Enterprise System Engineer III at UTSA OIT
job_title: Enterprise Systems Engineer III in San Antonio, TX
pros:
Within UTSA OIT there is a dynamic environment with always something new to learn.
The teams work well together and "own" their respective pieces of the IT infrastructure.
My immediate managers were experienced enough to let us work without constantly asking for status updates or micro-managing, and flexible when it came to personal life matters.
I am grateful to them for sending me to training for my RHCSA - an expense I would not have been able to afford on my own;  ultimately, it also helped me move on to the company I'm currently with.
cons:
The position I achieved was the peak of my career ladder there.  It seemed that only lateral moves were going to be possible - ie DBA or developer - and without any salary increase.  Titles "promotions" are the norm.
The office politics are thick.  
The upper management I was under likes to play 'King of Thrones' and doesn't seem to give two cents about employee morale.

review_title: Working as a research and teaching assistant
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in San Antonio, TX
pros: I get to teach the class I like the way I want to teach it.  Some students are great and it's a reward to teach them and engage them in discussions.
cons: Hours can be very random.  If you have to teach a "canned" class, you might not enjoy it very much.  Some of the professors have no clue what to do with you for research and assign meaningless tasks as opposed to something you could develop.  Finally, some of the students just don't seem to care and then they have the nerve to ask you for extra credit to help them pass the course - hey, why not come to class every day!

job_title: Director of Design in San Antonio, TX
pros: The benefits package is good: Health insurance, 401k, work hours, time off, discounts on college coursework, etc. The work hours are nice 8 to 5 usually. Benefit of working at UTSA is you can leave your work at work. You almost never have to take it home with you.
cons: The salary won't make you rich. Some people in the organization have been there a very long time and are set in their ways. It makes it difficult to change things or progress. They are slow to move on major decisions because nobody wants to take responsibility for fear that they will get in trouble. It is difficult to do anything beyond the ordinary.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Antonio, TX
pros: The position provides part time work for graduate students, assisting professors in their research and publications, and sometimes performing duties to help them manage their classes.  The position can also help pay most of the cost of attendance.  Furthermore, the schedule is usually pretty flexible.  If you have major tests or assignments, professors are usually very willing to hold off project due dates.
cons: The work experience differs based upon your supervising professors and department.  As a GRA, I have been fortunate to have had good professors to work for.  In some cases though, professors do not know how to delegate responsibilities or do not feel comfortable doing so.

job_title: Assistant Research Professor in San Antonio, TX
pros:
It is part of the UT system.
It is located in a nice part of the country.
cons:
It is a poor work environment for faculty and staff.
It is also a poor learning environment for students both undergraduate and graduate.
The admission standards and retention rate for students is also sub-par.
The administration functions in a fantasy land far removed from the reality the faculty, staff and students experience and focus on issues that are not relevant to the good functioning of the university.
The turnover in faculty and staff is also constant, usually the more competent individuals leave as soon as they get the opportunity.

job_title: Data Collection Support in San Antonio, TX
pros: Meta Data and Collections Support in the John Peace Library is an excellent place to do your Work Study. Time off is given whenever you need it to do work for your classes. They are very considerate to missing work, or setting up a schedule that meets your needs. The work is relatively free to do on your own. It is also easy and entertaining.
cons: The pay is low to other Work Study jobs. You have to put in more hours to get to your maximum allotment of work study money.

review_title: Great transition from school to career job.
job_title: Safety Department in San Antonio, TX
pros:
SInce working while attending school, I was given a schedule flexible for the classes I had. I think UTSA is a great place to work while in grad school..
Good health insurance and affordable vision/dental. 
Offered many resources for their employees such as free financial planning, discounts at many local retailers etc.
Upper management was very welcoming, even the President Ricardo Romo made an effort to talk to you when he was around campus.
cons:
Pay was less than competitive. 
I received a .25/per hour raise about 2 weeks before I was set to graduate. I don't know if that was supposed to encourage me to stay or move onto green pastures.

review_title: My Experience in Disbursements and Travel
job_title: Assistant Director in Boerne, TX
pros: I enjoyed being a part of a growing university and adapting to changes in its quest to becoming a Tier 1 University. I wanted to stay much longer than the 9 month I was employed there; therefore, I still continue to apply for other positions.
cons: Like any other work place, sections are ran differently. This section was busy, busy, busy! However, the only issue I believe that could've been approved  was it didn't appear that up-channelled complaints/concerns were addressed effectively, which could've leveled out the leadership/employee dynamics to make it a GREAT place to work regardless of the operation's productivity tempo.

job_title: Teacher Assistant in San Antonio, TX
pros:
The University of Texas at San Antonio serves the San Antonio metropolitan area  and the broader region of South Texas through programs and services offered from its three campuses: 1604 Campus, Downtown Campus and UTSA's Institute of Texan Cultures.

With more than 28,500 students enrolled in 130 undergraduate and graduate degree programs, UTSA is the second-largest component in The University of Texas System and has been one of the state's fastest-growing public universities for much of the last decade.

UTSA offers 64 bachelor's, 46 master's and 20 doctoral degree programs. With 10 doctoral programs and five more master's programs in the planning stages or awaiting final approval, UTSA is rapidly moving toward classification as a doctoral/research intensive institution.
cons: Library is not that good.

job_title: Financial Aid Student Assistant in San Antonio, TX
pros: Being in work study, there is more flexibility with your schedule. You have the opportunity to make your own schedule but it has to add up to approximately 19 hours a week. The people are usually friendly and you will receive an inside look on a lot of resources that a lot of students tend to over look.
cons: Although you are a work study student financial aid supervisors are a lot more strict than most of the other work study offices on campus. It is almost as if you are a full time worker, with just work study benefits, which is not much.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in San Antonio, TX
pros:
decent pay for students, the major benefit was the in-state tuition waiver which dropped the cost of attending from somewhere around 20k/semester to somewhere around 9k

As a research assistant I worked with a faculty member to write a research paper and aid in literature review.
cons: while most faculty want to help you there are the occasional few who see you as a hindrance; no benefits (health, retirement, etc) and you are explicitly limited to 20 hours per week  which effectively limits your income to around 10k/year

job_title: Associate Director in San Antonio, TX
pros: It's an 8 to 5 type of job in my area, and rarely am I bothered with work once I leave. My job is in Student Affairs so it can be exciting and energetic to work with college students and help them find their way in life.
cons: Parking is expensive, and cheap parking is unavailable. It is a State agency, so longevity is often rewarded over merit and efficiency. Very little opportunity to move ahead as most people in the line of succession for increasing responsibility aren't going anywhere. They are just seeking to max out their time so they can retire with the Texas State System.

review_title: A very friendly place to learn and teach in constant interaction with awesome people.
job_title: Teaching Assistant in San Antonio, TX
pros:
- Knowledgeable and helpful professors.
- Friendly, understanding and respectful people.
- Ease of access to the tools necessary to learn new things in the academic environment.
- Richness of recreational opportunities, such as gymnasium, intramural sport activities, student societies, extra curricular activities (outdoor trips, dance societies), opportunity of attending official basketball and football games.
cons:
- School's websites (blackboard and asap) would have more user-friendly interface.
- During busy times, it is difficult to find a free computer in library.
- Grade system is not clear, some classes are based on plus, minus system, some just have letter grades. University should have a standard.

review_title: Great Staff, Great Professors, and an overall wonderful experience
job_title: Supplemental Instruction in San Antonio, TX
pros: I worked as an SI and only did it because my professor requested me to do so.  It was a truly rewarding experience and had I known that it also gave me scheduling priority, I would have done it much sooner.  The SI staff was great to work with and it was a pleasure to get to know a lot of the professors on a more personal level.
cons: Only con would be that SI classes are generally in the morning whereas your upper level classes are in the evening.  Made for some really long days on campus.

review_title: This place makes things more difficult than necessary
job_title: Lecturer in San Antonio, TX
pros: Co-workers are great, students are friendly, and the benefits are pretty good. People try to be helpful and that promotes a spirit of camaraderie.
cons: Pay is terrible for similar positions at peer institutions. The infrastructure is very inefficient, and even the most basic task takes forever as a result. Many days, just trying to do a decent job seems like a battle.

review_title: Great place to work to begin my career in higher education, few downsides
job_title: Senior Program Coordinator in San Antonio, TX
pros:
- Great student development opportunities
- Great Benefits
- Family like culture among staff
cons:
- lower level employees get paid dirt, while the big wigs are rolling in dough.  
- Often can not move up unless someone else moves out, or you play favorites
- Receiving a higher degree does not automatically qualify you for a raise or promotion.

review_title: I enjoyed what I did and garnered great compliments, but very underpaid and not respected by higher ups.
job_title: in San Antonio, TX
pros: It's fun and you have relative freedom to be creative.  Every few months there is change, which keeps you on your toes and helps with the enjoyment.
cons: My department is the lowest in priorities and receives very little funding.  We have full-time people making lower than poverty range.  There is no respect or concern about this department.  This place is growing immensely, but all the money and time and energy is focused in other areas.

review_title: Project Manager within the Institute for Economic Development
job_title: Project Manager in San Antonio, TX
pros: The best part of working at UTSA was the overall employee atmosphere. During my time at UTSA the entire community welcomed me with open arms and respect.
cons: Unfortunately, merit increases were voted down during my tenure at UTSA.  This perk was seen as a necessary budget cut so that more monies could be put into the Tier 1 capital campaign.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Antonio, TX
pros: Lots of energy and enthusiasm at this emerging research institution! Young institution with great potential that is going places and is important to the San Antonio economy.
cons: For employees whose vision and passion is public higher ed that is accessible and affordable, changing demographic to a younger student body with higher test scores and better academic credentials makes it harder for some San Antonio residents to take advantage of what this local public institution has to offer.

job_title: Lab Teaching Assistant in San Antonio, TX
pros: Convenient location, flexible schedule, I was able to develop lasting professional relationships. Working as a Lab Teaching Assistant was not only fulfilling as a job, i was able to increase my knowledge on the subject matter greatly.
cons: As a student working as a TA, the pay is little due to the short hours. Review time spent with the professor was minimal, and I was required to be self motivated when grading/teaching.

review_title: Stability and benefits are excellent and offset the lower pay
job_title: Systems Analyst in San Antonio, TX
pros:
The stability of working for one of the top Universities in the state is good, and the benefits/retirement are excellent.  The University is expanding rapidly, but is also having issues with an overall decrease in student enrollment. 

Work/life balance is really good, for an IT salaried position there is not a lot of the "we own you 24/7" like in most industry positions.
cons:
Getting and keeping quality people is hard when the pay for an equivalent IT job is higher elsewhere. It seems that as soon as IT gets a good team together, the members of that team move on to other things and they have to scramble to replace them. 

There is a constant attitude of "we don't have the money to do that" so there are a lot of ideas that get scrapped at the lowest level without ever going higher, when we could do a lot more if the higher ups would let us.

Once you get into a position, there is little room for advancement where you can stay technical. There are only a small number of IT management positions, and those are held by people who have been in them for a really long time.

job_title: Supplemental Instruction Senior Leader in San Antonio, TX
pros: I have enjoyed working with the SI program at UTSA. SI has given me opportunities to work with colleges students and help them develop their skills to lead small group study sessions. The SI program also cultivates community extremely well, so much so that work acquaintances soon become like family.
cons: The only cons that come to mind are that time often seem to short when working with SI program and not a lot of growth of job growth, however still a solid job.

job_title: Associate Research Scientist in San Antonio, TX
pros: I can maintain my work life balance while fulfilling my duties. I am supervised by a professor who is understanding and supportive of the decisions I make.
cons: Some of the management offices mess up when it comes to processing things like time-sheets, sending out off-cycle paychecks or renewing job appointment.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in San Antonio, TX
pros: Friendly working environment, UTSA is rising in research and teaching in this area, benefits are almost same for other UT system universities.
cons: After 2011 the Graduate Research Assistant health benefits are not the same as the staff gets. Some departments have widely varying pay-rate (2/3rd monthly variation) among them for the Graduate Students working as a TA or RA.

job_title: Director in San Antonio, TX
pros: Good place to work, great benefits, and overall good leadership. Chance to reallly make a difference and love the team culture vibe in my area.
cons: Can't speak for all departments, it really depends where you work on campus and which divison but limited upward mobility and no raises. Overall salary structure is on the low side for what you do.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Antonio, TX
pros: Exciting personal and professional growth opportunities, with diverse fields of employment focused on education, research , and community service. Good benefits.
cons: Rapid growth of the institution means many challenges related to change, lack of standardized processes and business management systems, clarity of roles, frequent changes in management structure and direction may mean lack of recognition of individual contribution. Pay can be low in comparison to the workload.

job_title: Online Writing Lab (OWL) Teachers Assistant in San Antonio, TX
pros: Easy to get to classes, professors often willing to be flexible if you need to work around an important school project. Access to staff resources is usually available, for example industrial copiers - learn to use these.
cons: During crunch times for a class you might have difficulty juggling unexpected volumes of work with required study time, rare problem though.

job_title: AV Technician in San Antonio, TX
pros:
Excellent option for current students looking for an on-campus job
Willing to work around college class schedules and other jobs

Little prior experience required, training is offered and compensated

Job opportunity is limited to those enrolled at UTSA

Schedule varies with each week, with some weekends required
Work-Study grants are heavily preferred for hiring

review_title: It has been a growing, challenging, but very satisfying experience.
job_title: in San Antonio, TX

job_title: Student Admissions Officer in San Antonio, TX

review_title: Why you can not get a job at the University of Texas at san Antonio?
job_title: Small Business Researcher in San Antonio, TX

So, the job you are working as an intern or student assistant does not turn into a full time job and  goes to someone who does not necessarily allowed to work in the country. This is verifiable through cords either with Homeland Security or the University itself.

job_title: Specialist in San Antonio, FL

pros: They are investing much money on research right now.

review_title: At UTSA, I have experienced an inclusive community, friendly and supportive staff, and a professional atmosphere.
job_title: in San Antonio, TX

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in San Antonio, TX
pros: University is on the rise, as it pushes to become premier university.  Many opportunities to get involved innovative research in various fields.  You will learn a lot of tools and techniques that will be used in the future.

review_title: Office of Commercialization and Innovation Internship
job_title: Legal Intern in San Antonio, TX

review_title: Work experience was pleasant, co-workers rocked, and a very convenient as a work-study option.

review_title: A school with a lot of potential

review_title: They've Killed An Entire Profession - Academic Advising
job_title: Academic Advisor II in San Antonio, TX
pros: Good benefits, other people think it's a mark of prestige to work at a university, pretty decent days off, never had any problem with taking a day off.
cons: The people who run this school are unethical and dishonest.  The rot flows from the very top, this is a bureaucracy first, a corporation second and way, way down the list is education.  I've never seen an organization work at such cross-purposes, where everyone is only out to cover their own behind, where students are not educated at all, but simply processed through the sausage grinder.  I would NEVER attend this school or EVER encourage anyone I know to attend here.  Students are nothing more than cash cows. Staff are seen as nothing other than labor costs to be reduced.  This school pays drastically less than other schools for the same position, there is no merit pay, no pay raises and no advancement. There is constant turnover and low morale, about 40% of the advising staff left after these new changes were instituted, of course, without any consultation from those most affected.  Soon, all the advising jobs will be automated, seen that writing on the wall.
